question_category.name: Default for Module 2 Quiz
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Module 2 Quiz'.

question_category.name: Default for DI and Lesson Planning
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'DI and Lesson Planning'.

question.name: Module 2, Question 1
question.questiontext: Students will recognize and form irregular comparative adjectives

answer.feedback: Please try again.

Correct!

This LO is too general.  How do we measure “recognition”? It also contains two separate outcomes: “recognize” and “form.”

A specific LO could be: “Students will be able to complete a quiz on irregular comparative adjectives with 80% accuracy.”

question.name: Module 2, Question 2
question.questiontext: Students will be able to calculate the square footage of an area.

answer.feedback: Please try again.

Correct!

This LO is too general.  All areas? Rectangles and circles? Trapezoids? Irregular shapes?

A better LO might be: “Given the measurements of a figure, students will be able to calculate its square footage.”

Note that this LO would permit differentiation; figures of differing difficulty could be provided to students of differing readiness.

question.name: Module 2, Question 3
question.questiontext: Students will be able to write 5 sentences correctly using (1) capitals and (2) punctuation.

answer.feedback: Correct! This LO is specific about what student is to do and what is to be assessed.
Please try again.

question.name: Module 2, Question 4
question.questiontext: Students will be introduced to the progressive tenses.

answer.feedback: Please try again.

Correct!

This LO describes the content of lesson, not the outcome.

A better LO might be: “Students will be able to write 5 sentences correctly using the present progressive tense.” This LO could be changed to indicate the past or future progressive, or a combination. Or by saying “a progressive tense,” it could allow for differentiation by giving more difficult instructions to more advanced students.

question.name: Module 2, Question 5
question.questiontext: Students will be able to form at least five two-syllable comparative adjectives ending in Y.

answer.feedback:
Correct!

This LO is specific about what students are to do.
Please try again.

question.name: Module 3 - Q1
question.questiontext: Selected response (multiple choice) assessments should never be used in a differentiated lesson.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Selected-response assessments can be useful for determining student recall of facts.

Correct!

Selected-response assessments can be useful for determining student recall of facts.

question.name: Module 2 - Q1 (mult choice)
question.questiontext: Students will recognize and form irregular comparative adjectives.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

This LO is too general, and contains two separate outcomes.

This LO is too general - How do we measure “recognition”? It also contains two separate outcomes: “recognize” and “form.”

A specific LO could be:  “Students will be able to complete a quiz on irregular comparative adjectives with 80% accuracy.”

question.name: Module 2 - Q2
question.questiontext: Students will be able to calculate the square footage of an area.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

This LO is too general - All areas? Rectangles and circles? Trapezoids? Irregular shapes?

This LO is too general - All areas? Rectangles and circles? Trapezoids? Irregular shapes?

A specific LO could be:  “Students will be able to complete a quiz on irregular comparative adjectives with 80% accuracy.”

question.name: Module 2 - Q3
question.questiontext: Students will be able to write 5 sentences correctly using (1) capitals and (2) punctuation.

answer.feedback: This LO is specific about what student is to do and what is to be assessed.
Please try again.

question.name: Module 2 - Q4
question.questiontext: Students will be introduced to the progressive tenses.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

This LO describes the content of the lesson, not the outcome.

This LO describes the content of lesson, not the outcome.

A better LO might be: “Students will be able to write 5 sentences correctly using the present progressive tense.”

This LO could be changed to indicate the past or future progressive, or a combination. Or by saying “a progressive tense,” it could allow for differentiation by giving more difficult instructions to more advanced students.

question.name: Module 2 - Q5
question.questiontext: Students will be able to form at least five two-syllable comparative adjectives ending in Y.

answer.feedback: This LO is specific about what students are to do.
Please try again.

question.name: Module 3 - Q2
question.questiontext: A math teacher is working through a unit on fractions. The students have worked on proper fractions; the next step is to work on improper fractions. The teacher gives a quick quiz on the material covered so far to identify which concepts need more reinforcement or explanation. This is an example of formative assessment.

answer.feedback: The teacher is assessing how ready students are to move on to the next step in the unit.

Please try again.

The teacher is assessing how ready students are to move on to the next step in the unit.

question.name: Module 3 - Q3
question.questiontext: Assessments must always be differentiated.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.


Formative assessments are seldom differentiated, and summative assessments only when it is appropriate to the intent of the lesson.
Formative assessments are seldom differentiated, and summative assessments only when it is appropriate to the intent of the lesson.

question.name: Module 3 - Q4
question.questiontext: Rubrics are the best way of scoring differentiated assessments.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Rubrics are a useful for scoring complex products, but assessments may be differentiated in other ways that simplify scoring.
Rubrics are a useful for scoring complex products, but assessments may be differentiated in other ways that simplify scoring.

question.name: Module 3 - Q5
question.questiontext: An ESOL teacher wants her low-level students to be able to apply for library cards. She first reviews prior lessons about writing basic information such as name, address, and phone number, and then helps students fill out the library card application form. This is an example of a summative assessment.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

The teacher is helping students, and there is no indication that this is an assessment of any kind.
The teacher is helping students, and there is no indication that this is an assessment of any kind.

question.name: Module 4 - Q1
question.questiontext: DI requires that all learning activities must be differentiated.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Activities may be differentiated, but not all are required to be.
Activities may be differentiated, but not all are required to be.

question.name: Module 4 - Q2
question.questiontext: When content is differentiated, students must not have materials on the same topic.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Students may have materials on the same topic but differentiated by level or format.
Materials may be differentiated by topic, level, or format

question.name: Module 4 - Q3
question.questiontext: When process is differentiated, each student has a different activity.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Students may be assigned or choose to work in groups or individually.
Students may be assigned or choose to work in groups or individually.

question.name: Module 4 - Q
question.questiontext: When content and/or process are differentiated, assessment must also be differentiated.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Both formative and summative assessments may be differentiated, but it is not always necessary.
Both formative and summative assessments may be differentiated, but it is not always necessary.

question.name: Module 4 - Q5
question.questiontext: In differentiating content, readiness is always addressed by using tiers.

answer.feedback:
Please try again.

Tiers are only one way of differentiating content. Students may also have different roles in groups or use different materials, for example.
Tiers are only one way of differentiating content. Students may also have different roles in groups or use different materials, for example.
